channel.title: California
channel.description: California news and features from the Los Angeles Times.

item.title: Gimme Shelter podcast: Who should you inform if you live in an apartment complex and catch coronavirus?
item.dc:creator: Liam Dillon
item.description: If you live in an apartment complex and catch the coronavirus, you should inform people you've been in close contact with.
item.content:encoded: If you live in an apartment complex and catch the coronavirus, you should inform people you've been in close contact with.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 14: The Park La Brea complex, photographed on Thursday, May 14, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. The Park La Brea housing complex is the largest west of the Mississippi River. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Inland Empire will worship in person after state gives green light
item.dc:creator: Kailyn Brown
item.description: In addition to dine-in restaurants and in-person shopping, Riverside and San Bernardino counties are resuming in-person worship services.
item.content:encoded: In addition to dine-in restaurants and in-person shopping, Riverside and San Bernardino counties are resuming in-person worship services.

media:content.media:description: RIVERSIDE, CALIFORNIA - MAY 8, 2020: Residents who want public health orders rescinded attend an emergency meeting of the Riverside County Board of Supervisors at the County Administrative Center in the midst of the ongoing coronavirus pandemic on May 8, 2020 in Riverside, California. Type written notes are placed on chairs to keep people from sitting near each other. (Gina Ferazzi/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Orange County deems in-person church 'essential,' says rules too restrictive for megachurches
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: The Board of Supervisors unanimously approved a resolution supporting the resumption of in-person religious assemblies starting this weekend.
item.content:encoded: The Board of Supervisors unanimously approved a resolution supporting the resumption of in-person religious assemblies starting this weekend.

media:content.media:description: SANTA ANA-CA-APRIL 12, 2020: MaryAnn Lawson collects prayer requests from people gathering in their cars in a parking lot in Santa Ana to worship in an Easter service by Rev. Robert A. Schuller on Sunday, April 12, 2020. Schuller is reviving a practice that launched his father to worldwide acclaim- the drive-in ministry. For the past four years, the younger Schuller has been preaching primarily on social media, providing daily sermons from his "church with no walls." The COVID-19 outbreak - and the loss of in-person fellowship - led him back to his roots. "People need a place to go to worship on Easter, " he said. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California reopening further, but L.A. County still stymied by coronavirus numbers
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: Gov. Gavin Newsom announced that barbershops and hair salons would be allowed to reopen in 47 of California's 58 counties. Los Angeles isn't one of them.
item.content:encoded: Gov. Gavin Newsom announced that barbershops and hair salons would be allowed to reopen in 47 of California's 58 counties. Los Angeles isn't one of them.

media:content.media:description: CULVER CITY, MAY 6, 2020: Elaina Wilcox, owner of Color & Craft Salon is photographed inside her empty salon on Main St. in Culver City. The salon has been closed since March 19, 2020 because of the coronavirus. Wilcox , who said that her rent is $3200 a month and doesn't have an income right now, fears that she will lose her salon. (Mel Melcon/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Throngs of people, many without masks, pack Venice Beach over Memorial Day weekend
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: Californians cooped up for months under coronavirus stay-at-home orders crowded Southern California spots, pushing social distancing limits.
item.content:encoded: Californians cooped up for months under coronavirus stay-at-home orders crowded Southern California spots, pushing social distancing limits.

media:content.media:description: People walk at the boardwalk in Venice Beach during the first day of the Memorial Day holiday weekend amid the novel Coronavirus, COVID-19, pandemic in California on May 23, 2020. - Los Angeles County officials announced May 22, 2020, that beach bike paths and some beach parking lots will reopen and curbside service at indoor malls will be permitted. The county reopened its beaches a week ago but kept beach parking lots, bike paths, piers and boardwalks closed. (Photo by Apu GOMES / AFP) (Photo by APU GOMES/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Division scrutinized for allegedly falsifying interview cards issued the most in LAPD
item.dc:creator: Ben Poston, Leila Miller
item.description: LAPD division under scrutiny for allegedly falsifying field interview cards has played an outsized role in their production, a Times analysis found.
item.content:encoded: LAPD division under scrutiny for allegedly falsifying field interview cards has played an outsized role in their production, a Times analysis found.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIF. -- SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 21, 2015: Officers from the LAPD's newly expanded Metropolitan Division, stay with the driver and passenger, check them for tattoos while other officers search the vehicle in Los Angeles, Calif., on Nov. 21, 2015. (Marcus Yam / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: With clubs closed, underground parties thrive in Hollywood Hills. Authorities are cracking down
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton
item.description: The L.A. city attorney and LAPD are warning homeowners they can be held accountable for renter's parties during the coronavirus restrictions.
item.content:encoded: The L.A. city attorney and LAPD are warning homeowners they can be held accountable for renter's parties during the coronavirus restrictions.

media:content.media:description: Famous Hollywood sign atop Mt. Lee.

item.title: Earthquake: 3.6 quake near El Centro, Calif.
item.dc:creator: Quakebot
item.description: A magnitude-3.6 earthquake was reported Tuesday at 12:53 p.m. near El Centro, Calif.
item.content:encoded: A magnitude-3.6 earthquake was reported Tuesday at 12:53 p.m. near El Centro, Calif.

media:content.media:description: A magnitude 3.5 earthquake was reported Tuesday afternoon May 26, 2020, at 12:53 p.m. Pacific time 11 miles from El Centro, Calif.

item.title: Hair salons, barbershops can reopen now, in Stage 3 of Newsom's plan
item.dc:creator: Taryn Luna
item.description: Gov. Newsom said California barbershops, hair salons, nail salons and other grooming services could reopen under Stage 3 of his reopening plan. Nothing would immediately change in LA County.
item.content:encoded: Gov. Newsom said California barbershops, hair salons, nail salons and other grooming services could reopen under Stage 3 of his reopening plan. Nothing would immediately change in LA County.

media:content.media:description: YUBA CITY, CA -- MAY 06: Wes Heryford, center, owner, who has been cutting hair for over 24-years, works on Ben Martin, 25, at Butte House Barber Shop on Wednesday, May 6, 2020, in Yuba City, CA. Heryford closed his business on March 22 due to the coronavirus and opened on March 5th. "It was difficult to pay my bills and make ends meet for my family," said Wes. Sutter and Yuba counties, both north of Sacramento, are allowing businesses and restaurants to reopen, defying Gov. Gavin Newsom's statewide stay-at-home order due to the coronavirus pandemic. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 3 Metro buses catch fire in Carson; one person injured
item.dc:creator: Priscella Vega
item.description: It is unclear how the three buses caught fire at a transportation hub in Carson. One person had minor injuries.
item.content:encoded: It is unclear how the three buses caught fire at a transportation hub in Carson. One person had minor injuries.

item.title: Los Angeles opens its largest coronavirus testing site at Dodger Stadium
item.dc:creator: Priscella Vega
item.description: Los Angeles opens its largest coronavirus testing site at Dodger Stadium, where up to 6,000 people a day can be tested from their cars.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles opens its largest coronavirus testing site at Dodger Stadium, where up to 6,000 people a day can be tested from their cars.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES-CA-MAY 26, 2020: Drive-through coronavirus testing at Dodger Stadium in Elysian Park on Tuesday, May 26, 2020. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Eaton Canyon closed till June 1 after being overrun by visitors
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth, Luke Money
item.description: The Pasadena hiking spot was shut down Sunday after visitors, many not practicing social distancing due to coronavirus outbreak, crowded the trails.
item.content:encoded: The Pasadena hiking spot was shut down Sunday after visitors, many not practicing social distancing due to coronavirus outbreak, crowded the trails.

media:content.media:description: PASADENA, CA - MAY 24: Visitors stream into and out of Eaton Canyon Natural Area Park on Sunday, May 24, 2020 in Pasadena, CA during the Memorial Day weekend. Signs and park volunteers reminded visitors to wear their masks. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Myung J. Chun/Myung J. Chun/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Coronavirus 'silent spreaders' become a bigger risk as California reopens
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II
item.description: There's increasing concern that people infected with COVID-19 who show no signs of illness are playing a large role in the transmission of COVID-19.
item.content:encoded: There's increasing concern that people infected with COVID-19 who show no signs of illness are playing a large role in the transmission of COVID-19.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 22: Hainan Airlines flight crew in full biohazard suit at Tom Bradley Terminal. Due to global pandemic and upcoming Memorial Day Weekend travelers are strongly advised to follow mask and social distancing recommendations at Los Angeles International Airport. Los Angeles Airport LAX on Friday, May 22, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Heat wave to bake parts of Southern California, dry out vegetation that can fuel fires
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: Triple-digit temperatures are expected in some Southern California inland areas, while the valleys will reach the 90s, according to the weather service.
item.content:encoded: Triple-digit temperatures are expected in some Southern California inland areas, while the valleys will reach the 90s, according to the weather service.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 26: Smokey Bear wears a protective face mask as he warns of High Fire Danger at the Riverside Drive and Los Feliz Blvd entrance to Griffith Park in Los Angeles Tuesday, May 26, 2020 as the Southland's latest heat wave will send the mercury soaring into triple-digit territory raising the risk of heat-related illnesses. In some locations an excessive heat warning will be in effect and temperatures are forecast to be around 20 degrees higher than normal. But even where no excessive warning has been issued ... the heat will be brutal ... especially for those working or participating in outdoor activities.... Griffith Park on Tuesday, May 26, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California's battle over reopening churches isn't over despite new coronavirus rules
item.dc:creator: Monte Morin, Alex Wigglesworth, Mike Freeman
item.description: The state's plan will alter religious services in dramatic ways, and it's unlikely to end the push by some churches to allow more regular worship operations.
item.content:encoded: The state's plan will alter religious services in dramatic ways, and it's unlikely to end the push by some churches to allow more regular worship operations.

media:content.media:description: SOUTH PASADENA, CA APRIL 5, 2020: Fr Joe O'Neill gives Mass during the coronavirus pandemic Holy Family Church is closed to the public in South Pasadena, CA April 5, 2020. Normally the church would be filled with parishioners on Palm Sunday. Today the church is livestreaming their Masses. While the church remains closed they say they have more than 10,000 visitors through their our livestreamed Masses. This is the third Mass today during Palm Sunday. (Francine Orr/ Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Francine Orr/Francine Orr/Francine Orr/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Banks: Once homeless, a student loses 100 pounds and fends off isolation with teachers' help
item.dc:creator: Sandy Banks
item.description: A Los Angeles high school student fights cornonvirus isolation and distance learning struggles with help from his teachers.
item.content:encoded: A Los Angeles high school student fights cornonvirus isolation and distance learning struggles with help from his teachers.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 21: Keith Wallick, 17,poses for a portrait in his neighborhood South L.A. on Thursday, May 21, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. Wallick now lives with his older brother in an apartment in South LA . Wallick struggled in school, until he found art at Santee High School. He is now graduatin with a choice of scholarships to three different college arts programs, and has lost over 100 pounds. (Gabriella Angotti-Jones / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Despite a budget crisis, L.A. officials give new bonuses to officers with college degrees
item.dc:creator: David Zahniser, Dakota Smith
item.description: LAPD officers with college degrees have begun receiving a new education bonus, even as civilian city employees are targeted for furloughs.
item.content:encoded: LAPD officers with college degrees have begun receiving a new education bonus, even as civilian city employees are targeted for furloughs.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIF. -- MONDAY, JANUARY 28, 2019: Mayor Eric Garcetti, right, listens to LAPD Chief Michel Moore announce that for the first time in five years, violent crime was down in Los Angeles in 2018, with the number of homicides on track to be among the lowest in more than 50 years during a press conference at LAPD headquarters in Los Angeles, Calif., on Jan. 28, 2019. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Facing schedule delays, L.A. Metro seeks $120 million more for Crenshaw Line
item.dc:creator: Laura J. Nelson
item.description: L.A. County transportation officials are seeking $120 million more to complete the $2-billion Crenshaw Line, which will run from Mid-City to the South Bay.
item.content:encoded: L.A. County transportation officials are seeking $120 million more to complete the $2-billion Crenshaw Line, which will run from Mid-City to the South Bay.

media:content.media:description: Artist's rendering of the Crenshaw Line's Century/Aviation station. Officials approved another station Thursday just to the north, at Aviation Boulevard and 96th Street.

item.title: California allows many more retail stores to reopen
item.dc:creator: Monte Morin
item.description: The existing guidance for retailers now applies statewide. It marks the latest move to slowly reopen California's economy amid the coronavirus outbreak.
item.content:encoded: The existing guidance for retailers now applies statewide. It marks the latest move to slowly reopen California's economy amid the coronavirus outbreak.

media:content.media:description: Doug Jordan owner of Java Junction at The Grossmont Center, an outdoor shopping mall in La Mesa, opened his store for the first time since closing in March. The mall opened to the public today with a few gift shops, formal dress shops and a few of the small eat in dining restaurants. Late Wednesday night the State of California approved San Diego County's plan for Phase 2 of the reopening plan.
media:content.media:credit: Nelvin C. Cepeda/The San Diego Union-Tribune

item.title: L.A. County COVID-19 cases top 46,000 on Memorial Day
item.dc:creator: Tony Barboza
item.description: Los Angeles County reported 12 new coronavirus deaths and an additional 1,047 cases Monday.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles County reported 12 new coronavirus deaths and an additional 1,047 cases Monday.

media:content.media:description: Children place a flowers at the graves of fallen soldiers to pay their respects during Memorial Day observances at the Los Angeles National Cemetery to honor fallen soldiers and health care workers in Los Angeles, Monday, May 25, 2020. The annual Memorial Day commemoration at the cemetery was held without the public in attendance due to the coronavirus outbreak. (AP Photo/Richard Vogel)

item.title: On Memorial Day, Southern California honors fallen service members and those on the front line of coronavirus crisis
item.dc:creator: Rosanna Xia, Harriet Ryan
item.description: With social distancing rules in place, Memorial Day ceremonies across Southern California were replaced by virtual gatherings.
item.content:encoded: With social distancing rules in place, Memorial Day ceremonies across Southern California were replaced by virtual gatherings.

media:content.media:description: President Donald Trump salutes after placing a wreath at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier in Arlington National Cemetery, in honor of Memorial Day, Monday, May 25, 2020, in Arlington, Va. (AP Photo/Alex Brandon)

item.title: Farmer John meatpackers demand closing of Vernon plant struck by COVID-19 outbreak
item.dc:creator: Harriet Ryan
item.description: The union representing workers at the Vernon plant that makes Dodger Dogs said the facility should be shut down pending cleaning and an investigation.
item.content:encoded: The union representing workers at the Vernon plant that makes Dodger Dogs said the facility should be shut down pending cleaning and an investigation.

media:content.media:description: VERNON, CA - NOVEMBER 3, 2017: Farmer John located at Soto St and E. 37th Street in Vernon Friday November 3, 2017 as air quality officials are expected to adopt new rules aimed at easing foul odors from animal rendering plants. Nearby Boyle Heights residents have long complained for about stomach-churning odors wafting over from five Vernon-area rendering plants, which take animal parts from slaughterhouses and cook them down into fats and proteins that are used to make pet food, fertilizer, cosmetics and products. The new standards, which took over three years for regulators to develop amid pushback from the industry, will require facilities enclose some of their outdoor animal processing operations, use odor-control equipment and take other steps to minimize offensive odors. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California limits church capacity to 25% for reopening, adds other restrictions
item.dc:creator: Monte Morin
item.description: California has released new coronavirus health guidance for religious services, limiting total attendance to 25% of a building's capacity.
item.content:encoded: California has released new coronavirus health guidance for religious services, limiting total attendance to 25% of a building's capacity.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - APRIL 10: Archbishop Jose Gomez, Father Brian Nunez and Father Raymont Medina celebrate Good Friday liturgy in a nearly empty Cathedral of Our Lady of the Angels to guard against the coronavirus on Friday, April 10, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug/Brian van der Brug/Los Angeles Times

item.description: Los Angeles County reported 913 new COVID-19 cases and 16 additional deaths Sunday, bringing total confirmed cases to 45,034 and fatalities to 2,108.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles County reported 913 new COVID-19 cases and 16 additional deaths Sunday, bringing total confirmed cases to 45,034 and fatalities to 2,108.

item.content:encoded: Large Memorial Day events in Los Angeles, Orange and San Diego counties are being replaced by virtual ones.

media:content.media:description: Nihil Smith pays respect to his longtime friend U.S. Marine Corps Lt. Col. Kenneth Pipes, a Silver Star and Purple Heart recipient at Fort Rosecrans National Cemetery on May 24, 2020, a day before Memorial Day.

item.title: Column: California gives too many unchecked tax breaks. It's time to shine a light on them
item.dc:creator: George Skelton
item.description: State Sen. Hannah-Beth Jackson is pushing a bill — SB 956 — that would authorize an economic team at UC Berkeley to examine certain major tax breaks.
item.content:encoded: State Sen. Hannah-Beth Jackson is pushing a bill — SB 956 — that would authorize an economic team at UC Berkeley to examine certain major tax breaks.

media:content.media:description: State Sen. Hannah-Beth Jackson (D-Santa Barbara), shown during a floor debate earlier this week, authored a measure to enhance privacy protections for Internet consumers.

item.title: Coronavirus outbreaks hits Farmer John, 8 other plants in Vernon
item.dc:creator: Laura Newberry
item.description: Coronavirus outbreaks hits Farmer John and other food processing plants in Vernon.
item.content:encoded: Coronavirus outbreaks hits Farmer John and other food processing plants in Vernon.

media:content.media:description: VERNON, CA - NOVEMBER 3, 2017: Farmer John located at Soto St and E. 37th Street in Vernon Friday November 3, 2017 as air quality officials are expected to adopt new rules aimed at easing foul odors from animal rendering plants. Nearby Boyle Heights residents have long complained for about stomach-churning odors wafting over from five Vernon-area rendering plants, which take animal parts from slaughterhouses and cook them down into fats and proteins that are used to make pet food, fertilizer, cosmetics and products. The new standards, which took over three years for regulators to develop amid pushback from the industry, will require facilities enclose some of their outdoor animal processing operations, use odor-control equipment and take other steps to minimize offensive odors. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Suspension of military honors at national cemetery burials compounds loss for families
item.dc:creator: Andrew Dyer
item.description: Without honor guards, gun salutes or folded flag ceremonies, families of recently deceased veterans say closure is hard to find.
item.content:encoded: Without honor guards, gun salutes or folded flag ceremonies, families of recently deceased veterans say closure is hard to find.

item.title: How coronavirus has upended life for thousands at California's largest apartment complex
item.dc:creator: Liam Dillon
item.description: Nowhere in L.A. are the logistical, financial and health complications of the coronavirus on greater display than at the huge complex Park La Brea.
item.content:encoded: Nowhere in L.A. are the logistical, financial and health complications of the coronavirus on greater display than at the huge complex Park La Brea.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 14: Sabrina Knight, who lives at Park La Brea, poses for a portrait on Thursday, May 14, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. The Park La Brea housing complex is the largest west of the Mississippi River. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: I live in an apartment complex. If I get coronavirus, am I supposed to tell people?

item.description: You might be wondering what to do if someone in your apartment complex gets coronavirus. How worried should you be? What would your landlord do?
item.content:encoded: You might be wondering what to do if someone in your apartment complex gets coronavirus. How worried should you be? What would your landlord do?

item.title: He was a Hollywood darling for fighting dog meat trade. Butchers say he staged killings; he denies it
item.dc:creator: Paul Pringle, Alene Tchekmedyian, David Pierson
item.description: Activist Marc Ching, whose work won support from Joaquin Phoenix, Matt Damon and other celebrities, denies paying butchers in Asia to harm dogs.
item.content:encoded: Activist Marc Ching, whose work won support from Joaquin Phoenix, Matt Damon and other celebrities, denies paying butchers in Asia to harm dogs.

media:content.media:description: The dogs inside the iron cage will be sold at Tomohon Market. Butchers in Indonesia and Cambodia have told The Times that Ching staged scenes by paying them to torture and kill the dogs on camera N including the one that was burned alive N in a manner far more cruel than the methods they normally employ.
media:content.media:credit: Ronny Adolof Buol/For the Times/Ronny Adolof Buol/For the Times/Ronny Adolof Buol

item.title: With masks, temperature checks and anxiety, California's retail economy gingerly reopens

media:content.media:description: VENTURA, CA - MAY 21: Bryson Finger serves coffee to Jeric Gambon, 24, as he enjoys breakfast at Busy Bee Cafe on Main Street in downtown Ventura Thursday morning as Ventura County has become the largest county in Southern California to resume dine-in service at restaurants and in-store shopping joining a growing list of California counties that have been given permission to enter phase two of reopening after closures due to coronavirus Covid-19. Downtown on Thursday, May 21, 2020 in Ventura, CA. Downtown on Thursday, May 21, 2020 in Ventura, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Animal rescue charity with star-studded support has 'troubling' financial practices, experts say

item.title: Role of extremist groups at California lockdown protests raises alarms
item.dc:creator: Anita Chabria
item.description: Lockdown protesters gathered for another rally at the California Capitol, where alt-right groups mixed with religious rights organizers, anti-vaccine advocates, others.
item.content:encoded: Lockdown protesters gathered for another rally at the California Capitol, where alt-right groups mixed with religious rights organizers, anti-vaccine advocates, others.

media:content.media:description: SACRAMENTO, CA -- MAY 23: A large crowd of roughly 2000 people gathers to attend 'Liberty Fest,' hosted by the Freedom Angels, outside the closed state Capitol building on Saturday, May 23, 2020, in Sacramento, CA. Demonstrators gathered to protest Gov. Gavin Newson's shutdown of businesses and religious gatherings amid the coronavirus pandemic. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Amid coronavirus crisis, L.A. County may create an inspector general to oversee nursing homes
item.dc:creator: Jaclyn Cosgrove
item.description: More than half of the deaths from COVID-19 in Los Angeles County have been in skilled nursing facilities. On Tuesday, the L.A. County Board of Supervisors will consider a motion to bring more accountability to those sites.
item.content:encoded: More than half of the deaths from COVID-19 in Los Angeles County have been in skilled nursing facilities. On Tuesday, the L.A. County Board of Supervisors will consider a motion to bring more accountability to those sites.

Nearby Boyle Heights residents have long complained for about stomach-churning odors wafting over from five Vernon-area rendering plants, which take animal parts from slaughterhouses and cook them down into fats and proteins that are used to make pet food, fertilizer, cosmetics and products. The new standards, which took over three years for regulators to develop amid pushback from the industry, will require facilities enclose some of their outdoor animal processing operations, use odor-control equipment and take other steps to minimize offensive odors. item.title: Pancakes, face masks, temperature checks: Ventura County restaurants reopen to customers, concerns
item.dc:creator: Kevin Baxter
item.description: Eating inside restaurants is now allowed in Ventura County.
item.content:encoded: Eating inside restaurants is now allowed in Ventura County.

South Central on Monday, May 18, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Orange County cleared to reopen more businesses amid coronavirus restrictions
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth, Hannah Fry
item.description: coronavirus: Orange County gets the OK for more aggressive reopening
item.content:encoded: coronavirus: Orange County gets the OK for more aggressive reopening

media:content.media:description: LAGUNA BEACH, CALIF. - MAY 2, 2020. Cops and protesters find a shady spot along Pacific Coast Highway in Laguna Beach on Saturday, May 2, 2020. California Gov. Gavin Newson ordered a hard closure of Orange County beaches this weekend. But responding to public pressure in recent days, Newson has implied that a gradual reopening of beaches, parks and the economy following the coronavirus lockdown could begin as early as next week. (Luis Sinco/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California just made it easier for bars, wineries, distilleries to offer to-go drinks
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: More California establishments can sell alcoholic beverages to go after the state relaxed a rule to help businesses during the coronavirus crisis.
item.content:encoded: More California establishments can sell alcoholic beverages to go after the state relaxed a rule to help businesses during the coronavirus crisis.

media:content.media:description: Bartender Taylor Osorio wears a face mask as she pours drinks at Centro Cocina Mexicana restaurant in Sacramento, Calif., Friday, May 22, 2020. As part of Sacramento County's extended Stage 2 reopening plan, dine-in restaurants and retail stores were allowed to open at noon Friday after being closed for several months due to the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: How L.A. County became coronavirus epicenter: Slower shutdown, density, poverty among theories
item.dc:creator: Soumya Karlamangla
item.description: Theories abound as to why L.A. County has the bulk of the state's confirmed coronavirus cases, but a clear explanation has been elusive.
item.content:encoded: Theories abound as to why L.A. County has the bulk of the state's confirmed coronavirus cases, but a clear explanation has been elusive.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIF. -- MONDAY, APRIL 6, 2020: Dusk settles as the Third street which is usually streaming with traffic, sits empty in downtown Los Angeles, Calif., on April 6, 2020. In California, there are more than 16,363 confirmed COVID-19 cases, according to a tally maintained by the Los Angeles Times. At least 387 have died. (Marcus Yam / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Memorial Day brings heat and warnings on outings amid coronavirus in Southern California
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth, Colleen Shalby, Hannah Fry, Luke Money

item.title: Massive fire strikes San Francisco's Fisherman's Wharf, spares WWII ship
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: A fire broke out before dawn on San Francisco's Pier 45 and tore through a warehouse, causing its walls to collapse, but a historic ship was saved.
item.content:encoded: A fire broke out before dawn on San Francisco's Pier 45 and tore through a warehouse, causing its walls to collapse, but a historic ship was saved.

media:content.media:description: First responders battle a massive fire that erupted at a warehouse early Saturday, May 23, 2020 in San Francisco. Arriving crews were confronted with towering flames engulfing the warehouse. (KPIX-TV CBS-Viacom via AP)

item.title: Magnitude 3.0 earthquake registered near Clovis, Calif.

item.title: California elections officials suggest schools as voting sites to ensure social distancing
item.dc:creator: John Myers
item.description: Elections officials from across California say they could use schools for voting this fall if campuses could close from Friday, Oct. 30 through Wednesday, Nov. 4.
item.content:encoded: Elections officials from across California say they could use schools for voting this fall if campuses could close from Friday, Oct. 30 through Wednesday, Nov. 4.

media:content.media:description: A voter fills in his ballot at a polling station in Sherman Oaks on May 21, 2013, the city of Los Angeles' election day.

item.title: Mosques adapt to coronavirus shutdown by sharing the call to prayer. In Culver City, neighbors said it was too loud
item.dc:creator: Brittny Mejia
item.description: Cities across Southern California have allowed mosques to broadcast the call to prayer publicly. But in Culver City, the adhan did not go unchallenged for long.
item.content:encoded: Cities across Southern California have allowed mosques to broadcast the call to prayer publicly. But in Culver City, the adhan did not go unchallenged for long.

media:content.media:description: CULVER CITY, CA - MAY 16: Mahmood Nadvi (Cq), left, standing on the rooftop, delivers Islamic call to prayers Adhan, summoning Muslims for obligatory prayers, at King Fahad Mosque in Culver City. In the midst of pandemic lockdown many mosques in Southern California got permission from local authorities to broadcast Adhan. in King Fahad Mosque on Saturday, May 16, 2020 in Culver City, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: As coronavirus stay-at-home restrictions ease, California casinos gamble on reopening
item.dc:creator: Kevin Baxter
item.description: On Friday, casinos across Southern California opened their doors to gamblers as some lockdown restrictions are softened.
item.content:encoded: On Friday, casinos across Southern California opened their doors to gamblers as some lockdown restrictions are softened.

media:content.media:description: CABAZON, CA - MAY 22, 2020: Patrons get their temperatures taken upon entering Morongo Casino which is reopening for the first time since closing on March 17 because of the coronavirus pandemic on May 22, 2020 in Cabazon, California. Patrons are required to wear masks. The casino reached full capacity within three hours of opening.(Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Card clubs offer reopening plan as tribal and Vegas casinos get back in the game
item.dc:creator: Hugo Martín
item.description: Coronavirus: Card clubs are working on protocols for reopening
item.content:encoded: Coronavirus: Card clubs are working on protocols for reopening

media:content.media:description: HAWAIIAN GARDENS CA. AUGUST 23, 2016: Card players try their luck at The Gardens Casino in Hawaiian Gardens on August 23, 2016. The Gardens Casino has undergone a $90-million overhaul and expansion. The card club previously operated out of a smaller tent. The tiny city of Hawaiian Gardens hopes the new card club will bring it added revenue. (Glenn Koenig/ Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Glenn Koenig/ Los Angeles Times / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Column: First one death in the family, then another, and the toll kept mounting for Inglewood couple
item.dc:creator: Steve Lopez
item.description: A healthcare activist has seen a grim example of healthcare disparities in his own family's COVID-19 tragedies
item.content:encoded: A healthcare activist has seen a grim example of healthcare disparities in his own family's COVID-19 tragedies

media:content.media:description: INGLEWOOD, CA - MAY 22: Holding a photo depicting members of his extended family, Tony Wafford poses for a portrait outside his home on Friday, May 22, 2020 in Inglewood, CA. Wafford, a healthcare educator at Oasis Clinic at Martin Luther King Jr. Community Hospital and his wife Diane Walker a retired Sheriff commander have lost relatives to COVID19 in a little more than a week. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Marin's health officer developed antibodies. He's now in a unique spot to fight coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Susanne Rust
item.description: Marin County's public health officer, Matt Willis, got coronavirus. Now recovered, he has ideas on how to help Marin County residents face the disease.
item.content:encoded: Marin County's public health officer, Matt Willis, got coronavirus. Now recovered, he has ideas on how to help Marin County residents face the disease.

media:content.media:description: Matt Willis, Marin County's Public Health Officer, sits in a meeting room with mask and banana peel at the ready, in San Rafael, Calif, on May 19, 2020.

item.title: Column One: They survived a school shooting. Then coronavirus stole Saugus High's senior year

item.description: When Adam Bratt studied the faces of his Advanced Placement psychology students that morning in December, he saw trauma.
item.content:encoded: When Adam Bratt studied the faces of his Advanced Placement psychology students that morning in December, he saw trauma.

media:content.media:description: SANTA CLARITIA, CALIFORNIA—NOV. 17, 2019—Students say the Pledge of Allegience as thousands gather at Central Park in Santa Clarita to remember those killed (two plus the shooter) and wounded in the Saugus High School shooting on Nov. 17 2019. (Carolyn Cole/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Column: Teaching the coronavirus outbreak in Los Angeles as a crash course in crisis management

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA NOVEMBER 20, 2014 -- Zev Yaroslavsky, member of the Los Angeles County Board of Supervisors on the rooftop balcony at the County Hall of Administration office on November 20, 2014 as he is preparing to leave the office he was elected to in 1994. Yaroslavsky served on the Los Angeles City Council from 1975 to 1994 and has been active in the areas of transportation, the environment, health care and cultural affairs. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: See's Candies reopens candy kitchens, paying attention to coronavirus concerns

item.title: Amid 2-day spike in coronavirus deaths, Orange County pushes for wider reopening

item.content:encoded: The county submitted final documents Thursday night showing it has met the state's benchmarks to move deeper into Stage 2 of reopening.

media:content.media:description: ORANGE, CA - MAY 21: Signs hang at Citrus City and Smoqued California BBQ as pedestrians walk by Thursday, May 21, 2020 in Orange. Signmakers - people who paint windows, make banners or A-frames, and other such stuff - has exploded as businesses try everything to get customers during coronavirus. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Corruption case against former L.A. County Assessor John Noguez tossed by appellate court
item.dc:creator: James Queally
item.description: The former L.A. County assessor was arrested in a 2012 bribery scandal, but an appellate court tossed the long-delayed case Friday after saying prosecutors missed a deadline that was tantamount to a violation of Noguez's right to a speedy trial.
item.content:encoded: The former L.A. County assessor was arrested in a 2012 bribery scandal, but an appellate court tossed the long-delayed case Friday after saying prosecutors missed a deadline that was tantamount to a violation of Noguez's right to a speedy trial.

media:content.media:description: New charges were filed against L.A. County assessor John Noguez, one of his former top aides and a tax consultant.

item.title: Trump administration warns Garcetti against 'heavy-handed' stay-at-home orders
item.dc:creator: David Zahniser, Dakota Smith, Joseph Serna
item.description: The Trump administration sent a letter to L.A. Mayor Eric Garcetti saying the Department of Justice is concerned the city may pursue "an arbitrary and heavy-handed approach" to coronavirus stay-at-home orders.
item.content:encoded: The Trump administration sent a letter to L.A. Mayor Eric Garcetti saying the Department of Justice is concerned the city may pursue "an arbitrary and heavy-handed approach" to coronavirus stay-at-home orders.

media:content.media:description: In his daily COVID-19 briefing, Los Angeles Mayor Eric Garcetti lays down plans for beginning phase two of reopening the city, what he called "baby steps forward." He detailed what businesses can reopen and issued guidelines for wearing masks while on trails or golf courses, which can reopen starting Saturday.

Parking lots, piers and boardwalks will remain closed. Beach on Tuesday, May 12, 2020 in Santa Monica, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Heat wave to arrive in Southern California just in time for Memorial Day

item.description: While coastal temperatures linger in the mid-70s, the mercury will rise significantly beginning Monday in the valleys and Inland Empire.
item.content:encoded: While coastal temperatures linger in the mid-70s, the mercury will rise significantly beginning Monday in the valleys and Inland Empire.

media:content.media:description: LONG BEACH, CALIF. - MAY 6, 2020. Jeremy Moskovitz practices physical distancing along with other visitors to Bluff Park in Long Beach, where temperatures reached into the low 90s on Wednesday, May 6, 2020. (Luis Sinco/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Sacramento County pulls plug on fitness studios, small gatherings after state intervenes
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: State health officials say gyms can't open and gatherings of any size are still forbidden in Sacramento County, even under relaxed restrictions.
item.content:encoded: State health officials say gyms can't open and gatherings of any size are still forbidden in Sacramento County, even under relaxed restrictions.

media:content.media:description: Gov. Gavin Newsom discusses his plan for the gradual reopening of California businesses during a news conference at the Display California store in Sacramento, Calif., Tuesday, May 5, 2020. Newsom warned counties that going too far in loosening coronavirus restrictions, could endanger public health. Display California, which sells locally-made items from around the state, is planning to open for curbside service on Friday under upcoming state guidelines. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli, Pool)

item.title: How to celebrate Memorial Day during the pandemic
item.dc:creator: Lila Seidman
item.description: Memorial Day will be very different in 2020. Instead of large gatherings with friends and family, try some of these alternatives.
item.content:encoded: Memorial Day will be very different in 2020. Instead of large gatherings with friends and family, try some of these alternatives.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JULY 04: Members of the military hold an American Flag on the field during the National Anthem before the game between the Los Angeles Dodgers and the San Diego Padres at Dodger Stadium on July 4, 2019 in Los Angeles, California. (Photo by Jayne Kamin-Oncea/Getty Images)

item.title: Actress Lori Loughlin and her husband enter guilty pleas in college admissions scandal
item.dc:creator: Joel Rubin
item.description: After maintaining their innocence for more than a year, Lori Loughlin and Mossimo Giannulli plead guilty to fraud in the college admissions scandal.
item.content:encoded: After maintaining their innocence for more than a year, Lori Loughlin and Mossimo Giannulli plead guilty to fraud in the college admissions scandal.

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this April 3, 2019 file photo, actress Lori Loughlin, front, and husband, clothing designer Mossimo Giannulli, left, depart federal court in Boston after facing charges in a nationwide college admissions bribery scandal. Loughlin and her husband Giannulli said in court documents Monday, April 15, 2019, that they are pleading not guilty to charges that they took part in a sweeping college admissions bribery scam. (AP Photo/Steven Senne, File)

item.title: Social distancing circles drawn on grass at San Francisco parks
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: Four San Francisco parks are being outfitted with social distancing circles to remind people to stay away from each other while outdoors during the coronavirus outbreak.
item.content:encoded: Four San Francisco parks are being outfitted with social distancing circles to remind people to stay away from each other while outdoors during the coronavirus outbreak.

media:content.media:description: SAN FRANCISCO, CALIFORNIA - MAY 20: New social distancing circles are shown at Dolores Park on May 20, 2020 in San Francisco, California. The move follows similar moves by other parks in cities around the world in an effort to get back to some semblance of normalcy. (Photo by Justin Sullivan/Getty Images)

item.title: Two Southern California men arrested in kidnapping, slaying of Santa Cruz CEO

item.content:encoded: Two of the four men arrested in last year's kidnapping and slaying of Tushar Atre in Santa Cruz worked at his cannabis business, authorities said.

media:content.media:description: Dan Coyro Santa Cruz Sentinel SANTA CRUZ COUNTY sheriff's deputies investigate at the home of Tushar Atre, who was kidnapped and killed Tuesday. Authorities said on Facebook that they believe the crime began as a robbery attempt.

item.title: As coronavirus deaths mount, L.A. County is far behind on promise to test everyone in nursing homes

item.description: As deaths mount, LA County far behind on promise to test everyone in nursing homes.

item.title: California's unemployment rate leaps to 15.5% as 2.3 million jobs vanish
item.dc:creator: Margot Roosevelt
item.description: "We've basically wiped out a decade worth of job creation in a month and a half," an economist says. May's unemployment figures will probably look even grimmer.
item.content:encoded: "We've basically wiped out a decade worth of job creation in a month and a half," an economist says. May's unemployment figures will probably look even grimmer.

media:content.media:description: CANOGA PARK, CA - MAY 14: Maria Mora came to find information about her claim but found the California State Employment Development Department was closed due to coronavirus concerns on Thursday, May 14, 2020 in Canoga Park, CA. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug/Brian van der Brug/Los Angeles Times

item.title: He's diabetic. He works a high-risk job. But to pay rent, he has no choice
item.dc:creator: Cindy Carcamo
item.description: During coronavirus, Americans increasingly rely on migrant workers, many in the country illegally, who have no protections or financial support.
item.content:encoded: During coronavirus, Americans increasingly rely on migrant workers, many in the country illegally, who have no protections or financial support.

media:content.media:description: SAN JOSE, CA -- MAY 20: Porfirio, 51, a migrant from Mexico, a diabetic which puts him at higher risk of suffering serious complications and dying from COVID-19, at his home on Wednesday, May 20, 2020, in San Jose, CA. Porfirio is a Bay Area medical maintenance technician earns $27 an hour painting and repairing rooms and hallways in clinics and hospitals, a job that puts him at high risk for catching the coronavirus. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Even as California reopens, some officials tell tourists to stay away
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: More than two-thirds of California's 58 counties have received approval to more quickly reopen as the state continues to loosen coronavirus-related restrictions.
item.content:encoded: More than two-thirds of California's 58 counties have received approval to more quickly reopen as the state continues to loosen coronavirus-related restrictions.

media:content.media:description: MORRO BAY CA. APRIL 2, 2019 - April 2019 of otters floating in the marina at Morro Bay in San Luis Obispo County. San Luis Obispo County's health officer Dr. Penny Borenstein has asked tourists to not visit as the county reopens shops and restaurants this week. (Marc Martin / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: SpongeBob Popsicles, anyone? Parents compel ice cream vendor forced indoors to 'come back'
item.dc:creator: Anh Do
item.description: Ed Hassan put the brakes on his ice cream truck business when the COVID-19 pandemic hit. Parents in north Orange County convinced him to return.
item.content:encoded: Ed Hassan put the brakes on his ice cream truck business when the COVID-19 pandemic hit. Parents in north Orange County convinced him to return.

media:content.media:description: TUSTIN, CA - MAY 20: Ed Hassan, the owner of Mr. Frost Ice Cream truck, makes his rounds selling ice cream, popsicles and snacks on Wednesday, May 20, 2020 in Tustin, CA. Hassan had been on lockdown for about six weeks, he took the time to repaint and reorganize his cargo van. But parents kept calling and calling him, he said, asking for entire boxes of Sponge Bob popsicles and begging him to come back. "I thought they wanted me at home so I was at home. But there are huge demands." (Gabriella Angotti-Jones / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Gov. Gavin Newsom's promise to feed California seniors falling short so far
item.dc:creator: Taryn Luna
item.description: Gov. Gavin Newsom's program to deliver meals to California seniors hasn't lived up to his projections.
item.content:encoded: Gov. Gavin Newsom's program to deliver meals to California seniors hasn't lived up to his projections.

media:content.media:description: ALHAMBRA, CA - MAY 20: Mildred ``Millie'' Stratton waves to a caravan of cars led by the Alhambra Police and Fire parading past her home, celebrating her 102nd birthday on Wednesday, May 20, 2020 in Alhambra, CA. Millie is actively a lay leader and sits on several committees at the First United Methodist Church in Alhambra. Millie, who has lived in Alhambra her whole life within two blocks, has three children, one of whom died, four grandchildren and three great grandchildren. When asked what she attributed her long life to, Millie answered, "A hundred years ago the air was clean, the water was clean we had no problem and my mother was an excellent nutritionist, and we had home-grown chickens. And so we had so much chicken, I didn't cook it for ten years after I was married. Because that's' what we could raise. Just about two blocks from here. It was a small town. We knew everybody. Now that's all changed." Millie says she also credits her faith in God and support and help from friends and family. Millie was asked to offer her words of advice: "Well, it's easy to say, you have to live each day without the stress." (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben/Allen J. Schaben/Los Angeles Times

item.title: As L.A. County deaths pass 2,000, a warning that 'the virus is still out there waiting'
item.dc:creator: Luke Money, Rong-Gong Lin II, Hannah Fry
item.description: Los Angeles County accounts for nearly 60% of the state's total COVID-19 deaths
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles County accounts for nearly 60% of the state's total COVID-19 deaths

media:content.media:description: VENTURA, CA - MAY 21: Ventura County has become the largest county in Southern California to resume dine-in service at restaurants and in-store shopping joining a growing list of California counties that have been given permission to enter phase two of reopening after closures due to coronavirus Covid-19. Downtown on Thursday, May 21, 2020 in Ventura, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: In a pandemic, no one wants to touch it. Why cash has become the new Typhoid Mary
item.dc:creator: James Rainey
item.description: Many retailers and consumers fear handling dollars and cents during the coronavirus pandemic. Some experts say it will accelerate the transition to a cash-free U.S. economy.
item.content:encoded: Many retailers and consumers fear handling dollars and cents during the coronavirus pandemic. Some experts say it will accelerate the transition to a cash-free U.S. economy.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 20: Maricela Moreno, manager at El Tarasco in Marina del Rey, disinfects cash at the restaurant. She said a lot of customers pay with Apple Pay or credit cards. Marina del Rey on Wednesday, May 20, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Myung J. Chun/Myung J. Chun/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Big Bear Lake to stop communicating or enforcing state's coronavirus stay-at-home order
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller
item.description: The city of Big Bear Lake no longer plans to communicate or enforce Gov. Gavin Newsom's stay-at-home health order, stating that it has no legal responsibility to impose the state's restrictions on residents.
item.content:encoded: The city of Big Bear Lake no longer plans to communicate or enforce Gov. Gavin Newsom's stay-at-home health order, stating that it has no legal responsibility to impose the state's restrictions on residents.

media:content.media:description: Big Bear Lake offers visitors who stay at the mountain resort town a discount on summer activities like a round of golf or a ride on Snow Summit's lift.

item.title: Sections of L.A. River to reopen for limited activities
item.dc:creator: Leila Miller
item.description: Fishing, bird watching and walking will be permitted in the Elysian Valley and in the Sepulveda Basin in Encino. Kayaking and other in-water activities will be forbidden.
item.content:encoded: Fishing, bird watching and walking will be permitted in the Elysian Valley and in the Sepulveda Basin in Encino. Kayaking and other in-water activities will be forbidden.

media:content.media:description: An ibis forages for food in the Los Angeles River near Long Beach. The river and the 225-acre Sepulveda Basin Wildlife Reserve that drains into it also are occasional resting spots for migratory birds. www.lariver.org/
media:content.media:credit: Lawrence K. Ho / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Autopsies of 34 who died in Conception boat fire offer grim new details
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton
item.description: Deadly Conception dive boat fire, coroner's records raise new questions over deaths
item.content:encoded: Deadly Conception dive boat fire, coroner's records raise new questions over deaths

media:content.media:description: The U.S. Coast Guard was involved in a massive rescue operation Monday morning after a 75-foot commercial diving boat caught fire off the coast of Ventura County, trapping dozens of people.More than 30 people were missing and officials said some died. Many on the boat, which was off Santa Cruz Island, were believed to be sleeping below deck when the fire broke out and appear to have been trapped.

item.title: Cleanup to resume at troubled Santa Susana Field Laboratory site
item.dc:creator: Monte Morin
item.description: After years of delay, the federal government will resume environmental cleanup at a former nuclear and rocket test site in the hills of Ventura County
item.content:encoded: After years of delay, the federal government will resume environmental cleanup at a former nuclear and rocket test site in the hills of Ventura County

media:content.media:description: A view of an inactive space shuttle test location at the Santa Susana Field Laboratory site in 2002. Most of the Simi Valley, California, property is owned by Boeing, which acquired Rocketdyne in 1996. (Los Angeles Times/MCT) ** HOY OUT, TCN OUT **

item.title: As sheriff defies subpoena on jails, watchdog plans another for Kobe Bryant crash records
item.dc:creator: Cindy Chang
item.description: The subpoena is part of an inquiry into whether L.A. County Sheriff Alex Villanueva covered up the sharing of graphic photos by deputies. Villanueva did not show at a meeting where he was called to testify on coronavirus in jails.
item.content:encoded: The subpoena is part of an inquiry into whether L.A. County Sheriff Alex Villanueva covered up the sharing of graphic photos by deputies. Villanueva did not show at a meeting where he was called to testify on coronavirus in jails.

media:content.media:description: This image taken from video on Monday, Jan. 27, 2020, and provided by the National Transportation Safety Board, shows part of the wreckage of a helicopter crash near Calabasas, Calif. The Sunday, Jan. 26 crash killed former NBA basketball player Kobe Bryant, his 13-year-old daughter, Gianna, and seven others. (James Anderson/National Transportation Safety Board via AP)

item.title: Some California courts start to reopen as coronavirus restrictions ease
item.dc:creator: Maura Dolan
item.description: Among the California counties reopening courts: Contra Costa, Santa Clara, Monterey
item.content:encoded: Among the California counties reopening courts: Contra Costa, Santa Clara, Monterey

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MARCH 21: The Stanley Mosk Superior Court in downtown Los Angeles is photographed on Saturday, March 21, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. Earlier in the week, California Governor Gavin Newsom issued a "Safer at Home" order to the entire state to help slow the spread of the Coronavirus as it sweeps across the world. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Ventura County reopens dine-in restaurants and in-store shopping
item.dc:creator: Cindy Carcamo
item.description: Ventura County has received state permission to reopen restaurants for dining in and to allow shopping inside many retail stores.
item.content:encoded: Ventura County has received state permission to reopen restaurants for dining in and to allow shopping inside many retail stores.

media:content.media:description: VENTURA, CA - MAY 21: Cal Youngblood, 75, is served breakfast by owner Raymundo Sanchez at Busy Bee Cafe on Main Street in downtown Ventura Thursday morning as Ventura County has become the largest county in Southern California to resume dine-in service at restaurants and in-store shopping joining a growing list of California counties that have been given permission to enter phase two of reopening after closures due to coronavirus Covid-19. Clay drove from Simi Valley to eat at Busy Bee Cafe for the first time in months as the restaurant holds special memories because his Mother worked there for many years in the 1960's. "I couldn't wait to come back." He said. Downtown on Thursday, May 21, 2020 in Ventura, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Popular trails prepare for massive crowds over Memorial Day weekend
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: At least two popular areas in Southern California are closing amid increased crowds while stay-at-home orders continue to be relaxed.
item.content:encoded: At least two popular areas in Southern California are closing amid increased crowds while stay-at-home orders continue to be relaxed.

item.title: Orange County reports highest daily death toll from coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry
item.description: Orange County recorded 14 new coronavirus-related fatalities Thursday, an uptick that officials attribute to outbreaks of the virus in nursing homes.
item.content:encoded: Orange County recorded 14 new coronavirus-related fatalities Thursday, an uptick that officials attribute to outbreaks of the virus in nursing homes.

media:content.media:description: SAN CLEMENTE, CA - MAY 18: Families practice social distancing while playing in the water and sand near the San Clemente Pier on Monday, May 18, 2020 in San Clemente, CA. Orange County beaches are currently open for active recreation, which includes swimming, surfing, and running. (Gabriella Angotti-Jones / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Proposed budget cuts threaten safe opening of California schools, leaders say
item.dc:creator: Howard Blume, Sonali Kohli
item.description: coronavirus: Officials doubt schools can reopen safely if they must cut budgets
item.content:encoded: coronavirus: Officials doubt schools can reopen safely if they must cut budgets

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this Tuesday, Sept. 11, 2018 photo, Assemblyman Tony Thurmond, D-Richmond, a candidate for Superintendent of Public Instruction, appears at a candidates debate hosted by the Sacramento Press Club in Sacramento, Calif. Thurmond is running against Marshall Tuck, a former charter schools executive. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli, File)

item.title: UC makes landmark decision to drop ACT and SAT requirement for admission
item.dc:creator: Teresa Watanabe
item.description: UC regents vote to suspend SAT and ACT testing requirements for admission, marking a turning point in the debate over standardized test scores.
item.content:encoded: UC regents vote to suspend SAT and ACT testing requirements for admission, marking a turning point in the debate over standardized test scores.

media:content.media:description: PEMBROKE PINES, FL - MARCH 06: A college applicant uses an SAT Preparation book to study for the test on March 6, 2014 in Pembroke Pines, Florida.
